fields.description: As the console server generates files (keypairs, csv, etc), they are stored in the session using a set of "file_cache" methods. Since the session data makes a trip across the wire for every request as a cookie, we should leverage the shared cache to store the file data. The switch is pretty trivial to implement. We would also remove the data from the cache once downloaded in the same way we remove it from the session today. We should remember that keeping some data around longer than necessary has security implications.
fields.summary: Switch "file-cache" from session storage to short_term cache

comments.body: Work has been completed on the "shared-cache" branch.

I will look into reverting to session storage if memcached isn't able to store the data. The current failure mode is that I never get a download dialog and nothing sent to the log... obviously needs work!
[~dkavanagh]: Instead of porting to memcached, why not switch the file generation to write to a file on disk that gets deleted after the respective file is downloaded?

The nice thing about the cache and session are that they both expire. Any sensitive information in them will not last long (much less time in the cache since the session expiration is so long).
Another thing about file storage is potential cross-talk between views. We'd need some protections from both unauthorized access as well as multiple writers. [~rusvika]]?

Is the suggested file to be stored on the proxy? It should be simpler to secure file storage on the proxy than memcached. For example, generating a randomly named temp (i.e., short-lived) file for each download with permissions only allowing access to the console user should be sufficient.
[~rusvika]: Yes, that's exactly what I was thinking w.r.t. using file storage on the proxy rather than memcached for generated files.

Using a random temp name, we could store that name in the session instead of the file content. That way, we'd have an easy way to correlate the file to the user/session. Any concern about files not being deleted? Unless we delete the cached files at startup, we'd likely get some left over files during normal operation.
As [~kgill] suggested, can't the file be deleted after it's downloaded?

Of course. I guess I should have re-worded that. I can imagine exceptional circumstances where files could be left behind (maybe a user clicks a link after they make a request which generates a file and the file never gets downloaded). I can think of remediation measures that would make this almost a non-issue.
- only allow 1 file per session, so any subsequent downloads would overwrite the previous (if it wasn't already deleted)
- maybe only allow 1 file per user, so another session would clean up for a previous one. Could have implications if a user id was shared between people.
- perform cleanup of these temp files when the console starts
- perform cleanup if we detect a session has ended on the server side.

I see what you mean. I suggest to delete a file after a short period (even if it wasn't downloaded) similarly to cache expiration, on session termination (if it happens before the expiration), and on console start.

The hard part is that we have no provisions for background tasks in the console architecture. The console doesn't run anything on behalf of the user without an active request pending. Now, that isn't to say we can't, but that is something new we'd need to add.
Perhaps an option is to use a python Timer to delete the file after an interval has expired. That would be light-weight since it would be blocked until it expires. We'd need unique filenames so that we didn't have a timer wake up and delete a file that was recently created. That means allowing multiple files per user/session. That would let us fire off timers and not have to track them at all. If they expire, the file is removed for sure. If the console is restarted, timers are all gone, but we can run a cleanup task for any left-over files at startup. [~kgill] ?

this begs the question, is all of this really easier than simply encrypting certain types of data that go into the cache? We could use the same key we use for session encryption (I've looked at the beaker.session encryption code).

Perhaps, that's why it's important to go over prons and cons of both solutions. Note that ideally the key for internal data encryption should be different from the session key, but otherwise the same mechanisms could be used. Also, as mentioned in GUI-1115, memcached would need to have some form of access control.
If we need an interval-based (or cron-based) scheduler for cleanup tasks in the console, https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pyramid_scheduler might be worth a look.

Looking at the Pyramid Scheduler, it's a lot more than we'd need. If we just need fire-and-forget deferred operations, python's built-in Timer class is fair less overhead and code. I was looking to see if the scheduler offered a way to interrupt or replace an existing task. It wasn't obvious that it offers that. Those features would give us a little more control.
Using file storage works if there is only a single proxy. It fails when we scale horizontally since we cannot be guaranteed to have the same host service to successive requests from the same client.
We've decided not to do this for security reasons.
